He shares recipes he’s been cooking, restaurants he’s been eating at, and more. It gets better: If you sign up for our newsletter, you'll get this letter before everyone else.When I moved to New York a gazillion years ago, I spent a lot of time posting up bar-side at Corner Bistro in the West Village. My go-to order was the grilled chicken sandwich. Healthier than a burger, I liked to tell myself, it featured a well-marinated, juicy breast touched with a nice char, and topped with some crisp iceberg and a generous amount of mayo, all on a squishy bun.It’s the kind of sandwich that feels indulgent but doesn’t plunge you into a food coma (hello giant fried-chicken sandwich!). It’s also the kind of thing you can, and will, make on repeat this summer, no deep fryer required.The Bon Appétit version, developed by Molly Baz, brings the grilled chicken sandwich into the 21st century. To start, it swaps breast cutlets for boneless thighs—more flavor, more juiciness, more forgiving on a fiery hot grill.Like any decent grilled chicken sandwich, it relies on a marinade to imbue the meat with oomph—in this case a mixture of Dijon, Worcestershire sauce (god bless, Worcestershire), garlic, and lemon juice. The key move is reserving half of the marinade to blend with mayo and cornichons for the sandwich’s special sauce.Photo by Stephen Kent Johnson, Food Styling by Rebecca Jurkevich, Prop Styling by Kalen KaminskiAnd while I’ll never be mad at a classic coleslaw, I really dig how Molly introduced a certain...restaurant-y sophistication with the addition of simply dressed shaved fennel.Little Gem lettuce (this century’s iceberg?) offers crunch and protects the bottom bun from soaking up too much juice. And yes, the recipe calls for tomato, but I’m waiting until they’re in season to add a slice.Through an odd twist, my mom now lives directly across the street from Corner Bistro. I haven’t been back in years for its grilled chicken sandwich.
